factoid: The man said, "Put on your white dress. I like it."
Princess Mary sobbed louder after the man spoke.
The doctor took Princess Mary's arm and led her to the veranda.
The doctor soothed Princess Mary on the veranda.
The doctor tried to persuade Princess Mary to prepare for her journey on the veranda.
After leaving the room, the prince began speaking about his son, about the war, and about the Emperor.
The prince angrily twitched his brows while speaking.
The prince raised his hoarse voice while speaking.
The prince had a second and final stroke after speaking.
Princess Mary stayed on the veranda after the prince had a stroke.
The day had cleared and it was hot and sunny.
Princess Mary could understand nothing, think of nothing, and feel nothing except passionate love for the prince.
Princess Mary had never felt such love for the prince until that moment.
Princess Mary ran out sobbing into the garden and to the pond along the avenues of young lime trees planted by the prince.
Princess Mary wished for the prince's death.
Princess Mary wanted the prince's death to end quicker.
Princess Mary wished to be at peace.
Princess Mary wondered what would become of her if the prince was no longer there.
Princess Mary wondered what use peace would be if the prince was no longer there.
Princess Mary murmured these thoughts while pacing the garden.
Princess Mary pressed her hands to her bosom while sobbing.
Princess Mary saw Mademoiselle Bourienne coming toward her with a stranger.
Mademoiselle Bourienne had remained at Boguchárovo and did not wish to leave it.
The stranger was the Marshal of the Nobility of the district.
The Marshal had come personally to point out to Princess Mary the necessity for her prompt departure.
Princess Mary listened to the Marshal without understanding him.
Princess Mary led the Marshal to the house.
Princess Mary offered the Marshal lunch.
Princess Mary sat down with the Marshal.
Princess Mary excused herself and went to the door of the prince's room.
The doctor came out with an agitated face.
The doctor said Princess Mary could not enter the prince's room.
The doctor told Princess Mary to go away.
Princess Mary returned to the garden.
Princess Mary sat down on the grass at the foot of the slope by the pond.
Princess Mary was not visible to anyone there.
Princess Mary did not know how long she had been there when she heard a woman's footsteps.
The footsteps were running along the path.
Princess Mary rose and saw Dunyásha, her maid.
Dunyásha was looking for Princess Mary.
Dunyásha stopped suddenly in alarm upon seeing Princess Mary.
Dunyásha said, "Please come, Princess... The Prince."
Princess Mary replied, "Immediately, I'm coming, I'm coming!"
Princess Mary hurriedly avoided seeing Dunyásha while running toward the house.
The Marshal met Princess Mary at the house door.
The Marshal said, "Princess, it's God's will! You must be prepared for everything."
Princess Mary cried angrily to the Marshal, "Let me alone; it's not true!"
The doctor tried to stop Princess Mary.
Princess Mary pushed the doctor aside.
Princess Mary ran to the prince's door.
Princess Mary thought, "Why are these people with frightened faces stopping me? I don't want any of them! And what are they doing here?"
Princess Mary opened the door to the prince's room.
The bright daylight in the previously darkened room startled Princess Mary.
In the room were Princess Mary's nurse and other women.
The nurse and other women drew back from the bed.
The nurse and other women made way for Princess Mary.
The prince was still lying on the bed as before.
The prince had a stern expression on his quiet face.
Princess Mary stopped short at the threshold because of the prince's expression.
Princess Mary told herself, "No, he's not dead—it's impossible!"
Princess Mary approached the prince.
Princess Mary pressed her lips to the prince's cheek.
Princess Mary stepped back immediately after pressing her lips.
The tenderness Princess Mary felt for the prince vanished instantly.
The tenderness was replaced by a feeling of horror at what lay before her.
Princess Mary felt horror at something unfamiliar and hostile in the prince's body.
Princess Mary felt horror at something terrifying and repellent.
Princess Mary hid her face in her hands.
Princess Mary sank into the arms of the doctor.
The doctor held Princess Mary up.
